This study investigates the treatment of dyes AY36 and AB80 using photo-Fenton (PF) and Electro-Fenton (EF) systems, powered by an off-grid photovoltaic system. Employing PF (400 mg∙L-1 H2O2) with EF, degradation reached 71.47% and 85.64% at 436 and 624 nm. The introduced off-grid photovoltaic system ensured energy supply. Notably, a reduction of 53.56% in BOD and 9.90% in COD was observed in the analyzed effluent. The integrated of PF and EF, energized by a photovoltaic panel, not only demonstrated energy efficiency but also emphasized the sustainability of the treatment, aligning with environmentally friendly and renewable energy principles in wastewater treatment. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Electro-Fenton Photo-Fenton Photovoltaic panel Off-grid system Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The continuous growth in consumption of the most varied products by the population directly affects the demand for various production processes. Consequently, there is an increase in the volume and characteristics of effluents discarded in the environment. With this, the presence of a series of contaminants is verified, whether they are drugs, sterile phthalates, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH), dyes, among other persistent organic compounds. When present, even in small concentrations, in wastewater samples, these compounds can confer metabolic changes to biota organisms [1,2,3,4]. Dyes are known and exploited for use in dyeing processes. These compounds are present in segments of the most diverse applications, such as the production of sanitizers. They are applied in such a way as to impart color to attract consumers. The concern about water quality arises since the products of this industrial branch are used extensively in cleaning activities, reaching water bodies also through the domestic sewage (Pavhithra et al. [5]). The dyes acid yellow 36 (AY36) and acid blue 80 (AB80) present in sanitizers, when used together, give a greenish color to cleaning products. In the literature, some works are found that aim to degrade these compounds individually [6,7,8,9], however, degradation tests that seek to treat this mixture in industrial effluents have not yet been found. When this type of persistent pollutant is present in complex matrices, it is necessary to verify the type of treatment used in the wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) ([10] This is because conventional treatments applied (physical, chemical and biological) sometimes need to be associated with other techniques, such as advanced oxidation processes (AOP) to treat these substances more efficiently [11]. Different types of AOP have been studied, and it is relevant to evaluate the way in which hydroxyl radicals are generated during treatment. In electrochemical processes, their formation can occur on the surface of the electrode or through the use of salts as electrolytes. The association of these processes with a light source (photoelectrochemical processes) can enable greater degradation of contaminants and reduce treatment time [12]. The use of photolytic reactors is linked to energy consumption, which can be minimized if you use renewable energy as a way to make treatment processes even more sustainable [13]. The use of photovoltaic panels in off-grid systems makes it possible to supply energy to effluent treatments in small and large industries. Year-round solar availability in tropical countries near the equator makes the use of photovoltaic panels a green energy source [14]. This, in addition to the low operating cost, requires little maintenance and is easy to handle and responds reliably. Considering the development of photovoltaic production in the world, it is one of the most promising technologies in the field of renewable energy and environmental sustainability [15]. Therefore, the association of advanced oxidative processes were applied to the degradation of dyes AY36 and AB80 in effluent from the sanitizer industry. For this, an off-grid photovoltaic system was set up to energetically feed the proposed treatment systems (Electro-Fenton and photo-Fenton), in order to make their combination an environmentally sustainable way, in time, enabling their application beyond the bench scale. 2 Methodology 2.1 Reagents and materials The degradation tests of the present work used hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) (Neon; 35% (previously standardized)); sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) (Modern Chemistry); potassium chloride (KCl) (Dynamics); ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) (Vetec) and n-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine (DPD) (Dinâmica). The last two were used as indicators for quantification of hydrogen peroxide and free chlorine, respectively. Sulfuric acid solution (0.1 mol·L−1) was used to acidify the medium, when necessary. For free chlorine quantification methodology, disodium phosphate (Na2HPO4) (Dinâmica), monopotassium phosphate (KH2PO4) (Dinâmica) and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (Dinâmica) were used. The dyes evaluated were acid yellow 36 (class: azo, CI 13065) (Polycrom Química) and acid blue 80 (class: anthraquinone, CI 61585) (Polycrom Química). The effluent treated in this work was collected in a sanitizing industry in the State of Pernambuco/Brazil, was doped with AY36 and AB80 dyes (10 mg∙L−1 each dye) and characterized according to physical-chemical parameters (conductivity, turbidity, oils and greases, chlorides, pH, chemical oxygen demand (COD), biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), series of solids and metals with methodologies described by the Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Wastewater [16]. It is important to highlight that the company in question does not treat its effluent internally, since it does not have an ETE, outsourcing the treatment of its waste. 2.2 Photodegradation of dyes in effluent For the photodegradation tests, an irradiation chamber composed of 3 lamps in series of the UV-C type (Philips, 90 W) was used, as well as graphite electrodes and a power supply (180 W and output current of 4.9 A) were employed for the electrochemical systems. The irradiation chamber and the electrochemical apparatus were powered by an off-grid photovoltaic system assembled as shown in Fig. 1 . The systems consist of a photovoltaic solar panel (BYD 335-PHK-36 Poly (335Wp)), a charge controller (MPPT Epever 30 A 12/24 V (XTRA3210N-XDS2)), an inverter (Hayonik - 750 W / 12Vdc / 220Vac / 60 Hz Modified Wave) and a stationary battery (Moura 12MN105). The degradation tests for the complex matrix were carried out based on a previous study carried out by Neves et al. [17]. To this end, preliminary tests for the sanitizer effluent made it possible to investigate the efficiency of the processes in an isolated and combined way (photo-Fenton and electrochemical). Electrochemical tests were investigated with or without the use of electrolytes (Na2SO4 and KCl, both at 0.05 mol∙L−1). and under UV-C radiation. Furthermore, in the combined trials, the treatments of 500 mL of sample were performed serially for a total experimental time of 240 min. In the association condition, the fractional addition of hydrogen peroxide (400 mg·L−1) (0, 30, 60 and 90 min, with additions of 100 mg∙L−1) was also investigated. This assessment is important, as studies show that adding H2O2 fractionally can improve treatment efficiency [18,19]. 2.3 Analytical method Dyes AY36 and AB80 were identified and quantified in an ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) spectrophotometer (ThermoScientific model). The monitoring of hydrogen peroxide consumption was carried out according to the methodology described by Santana et al. [20]. Free chlorine production was determined by quantifying the Würster compound formed using DPD as an indicator, using the methodology adapted from Standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater 4500-Cl G [16] and ISO 7393-2/2018 [5] (Fig. 2 ). The working solutions used for the quantification method mentioned in Fig. 2 were the buffer solution (100 mL) prepared containing 2.4 g Na2HPO4, 4.6 g of KH2PO4 and 10 mL of EDTA (0.8%) and the acidified DPD indicator solution (100 mL) containing 0.1 g DPD and 2.5 mL EDTA (0.8%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Sanitizer industry effluent The dyes used in the sanitizing industry, AY36 and AB80, were initially evaluated in different matrices, to verify the characteristic wavelengths (λ) of the components, as shown in Fig. 3 . It is noteworthy that the effluent matrix was doped with the dyes AY36 and AB80, with a concentration of 10 mg·L−1 each, in order to guarantee the evaluation of their degradation in a complex matrix. In Fig. 3, the spectrum of the aqueous matrix identifies the λ of the chromophore groups at 436 and 624 nm, referring to dyes AY36 and AB80, respectively. It is known that this type of matrix (effluent from the sanitizing industry) is made up of different types of compounds such as inorganic salts, dyes and stabilizers, which is reflected in the scanning spectrum. However, there is a slight increase in the absorbance value for the λ referring to the chromophores of each analyzed dye. The physicochemical characterization of the effluent is shown in Table 1 . The values in Table 1 for conductivity, turbidity, oils and greases and chlorides indicate the absence of any type of treatment within the industry where the effluent was collected. The variety of sanitizers produced by it (disinfectants, different types of soaps and degreasers) justifies the high values obtained for these parameters and, therefore, highlights the complexity of the effluents from the industry's production process. Still in Table 1, the presence of heavy metals is observed, however, the concentration of each element is within the maximum limits determined by the legislation in force in the country. The biodegradability index given by the BOD/COD ratio for the effluent is 0.31. For values above 0.3, this is considered an effluent capable of being biologically degraded when released into bodies [21]. Another relevant factor to be discussed is the presence of Fe in the system from the production process (endogenous) that can contribute to the occurrence of degradation of compounds via Fenton reactions. The presence of iron in the process can sequester active radicals and therefore reduce the percentage of degradation of the compounds present in the investigated matrix. In addition, the high number of solids found in the collected effluent was due to the absence of any type of treatment, such as submission to grating, for example. In this way, it is necessary that the effluent generated undergoes adequate treatment to guarantee the disposal standards. 3.2 Preliminary tests 3.2.1 Photo-Fenton tests The effluent matrix doped with AY36 and AB80 dyes was initially submitted to photo-Fenton tests using different concentrations of hydrogen peroxide ([H2O2]) (Table 2 ). It is observed in Table 2 that the increase in the concentration of the oxidizing agent, from 80 to 480 mg∙L−1, increased the percentage of degradation for the two λ after 120 min of treatment. This fact is expected, considering a greater formation of active radicals (especially hydroxyl radicals) formed by homolytic breakdown in the presence of UV-C radiation. From the concentration of 560 mg∙L−1, there is a reduction in the degradation percentages. This effect occurs due to the excess of H2O2 in the reaction medium, which enables the formation of radicals with lower oxidation potential. On the other hand, the excess of hydroxyl radicals in the system can also lead to their recombination forming radicals such as superoxide and hydroperoxyl, thus reducing the oxidation power of active radicals present in the effluent to be treated. In this way, the greatest degradation of the dyes in the effluent was verified using a [H2O2] of 480 mg∙L−1 (Table 2) reaching reductions equal to 67.47 and 80.20% for the λ of 436 and 624 nm, respectively. However, from the point of view of residual [H2O2], its concentration at the end of 120 min was 174.85 mg∙L−1, while for 400 mg∙L−1 oxidizing agent a residual of 117.90 mg∙L−1 was obtained, with degradations of 65.78 and 80.19%, in that order. Thus, the concentrations of 400 mg∙L−1 was considered for the following tests. In order to evaluate the degradation without the need to add an oxidizing agent to the system, tests were carried out using an electrochemical system. 3.2.2 Electrochemical tests The initial degradation tests for this other AOP were carried out with and without the presence of the combination of electrolytes KCl and Na2SO4, both at 0.05 mol∙L−1. Additionally, we sought to verify the influence of UV-C radiation on the percentage of λ degradation (Table 3 ). In Table 3, it is noted that the tests with addition of electrolytes and absence of UV-C radiation showed a higher percentage of degradation for both λ. However, for these experimental conditions, a great detachment of the graphite electrode was observed with the advancement of the experimental time, a fact that can be explained by the high value of electrical conductivity of the industrial effluent (1146.30 μS·cm−1). It is worth mentioning that the excessive increase of this parameter in the medium can cause the scavenging of active radicals, generating unwanted by-products during the treatment [22], interfering, therefore, in the degradation efficiency obtained in the treatments for the analyzed dyes. In view of this, it is known that studies carried out in the literature emphasize the need for more than one treatment method for effluents from different types of industry. This is because its complex and recalcitrant nature requires the application of more than one treatment method, being the processes that make the integration of multiple techniques more effective for complex matrices [23,24]. In this way, the investigation of the association between photo-Fenton and photoelectrochemical processes was continued. 3.3 Combined tests In order to evaluate the combination of different types of advanced oxidative processes, it was determined that EF, without electrolyte addition (in situ), would be evaluated along with PF ([H2O2] = 400 mg∙L−1). Thus, the use of the same experimental time for the processes (120 min) was established, with the results obtained shown in Table 4 . According to the different assays (Table 4), it is noted that the combination of EF + PF and PF* + EF systems showed a degradation >71% for λ = 436 nm and 85% λ = 624 nm, more efficient configurations of treatment. Bearing in mind that the difference between these treatments was <5%, the concentrations of free chlorine and residual hydrogen peroxide were analyzed after 240 min, in order to verify which of the systems presented the lowest values. It was shown that free chlorine and residual H2O2, for the PF* + EF system, reached concentrations equal to 62.19 and 60.97 mg∙L−1, respectively. For the EF + PF systems, the concentration values obtained were 14.03 mg∙L−1 (free chlorine) and 163.04 mg∙L−1 (residual H2O2). With these data in hand, it can be seen that although the value obtained for residual chlorine presented for the EF + PF treatment was lower than that obtained for PF* + EF, the residual concentration for H2O2 was 2.67 times higher. Thus, it can be inferred that the use of electrochemical oxidation after the photo-Fenton system with fractional addition of oxidant allowed the continuous consumption of H2O2 after the initial 120 min of the treatment. It is verified in Table 4 that the residual values for the oxidants in the PF + PEF association were 53.88 and 58.68 mg∙L−1, respectively for H2O2 and free chlorine. The presence of UV-C radiation during both processes allowed lower values associated with the evaluated oxidants. This fact also influenced the reduction of the percentage of degradation for the characteristic wavelengths. This fact can be explained by the generation of other radicals in the reaction medium influenced by the heterogeneous composition of the effluent, such as Cl2, HClO, ClO−, •OH, S2O2−, C2O2−, P2O8 4−[1]. Thus, depending on the combination of treatments, the values obtained for [H2O2] residual and [Cl] free also varied. For this reason, the combination of (PF* + EF) was chosen for further investigations, by monitoring the concentration of oxidizing agents in the middle of the degradation assessment (%) (Fig. 4(a)). In Fig. 4, the initial 30 min of degradation promoted the treatment of >40% of the evaluated wavelengths. At the end of the 120 min of photo-Fenton, it was possible to reach 64.36% and 77.37% for λ 436 and 624 nm, respectively, reaching at the end of the electrochemical process (after 240 min of total treatment time) degradations of 71.47% and 85.64%, in that order. Although the percentage increase was around 7% for both λ, from 120 to 240 min, with the analysis of oxidants present throughout the reaction, the residual H2O2 concentration reached 189.91 mg·L−1 at the end of the first 120 min of treatment. Considering that the total amount of oxidant added was 400 mg·L−1, the use of this reagent in a fractional way over time did not allow an overload of oxidant in the system. In this way, it is possible to reduce the competitive reactions of oxidant consumption, in addition to avoiding the formation of both •O2H and •OH in excess, a fact that therefore reduces secondary reactions during the oxidation process [25]. With regard to free chlorine throughout the treatment, it can be seen in Fig. 4(b) that the oxidant reached 18.63 mg·L−1 at the end of photo-Fenton. This fact can be explained by the high initial concentration of chlorides present in the industrial effluent (see Table 1). When passing to the electrochemical system, already in the first 30 min of treatment, the system reached 51.71 mg·L−1. This is because the high conductivity, associated with the presence of electrolytes in the medium, allows the generation of electroactive species through indirect oxidation in the electrodes [26]. Thus, at the end of 240 min, the final concentration of free chlorine was 62.19 mg·L−1. For a better analysis of the treatment, the physical-chemical parameters of the sample were determined at the end of the 240 min of the experiment. It is noted in Table 5 that there was a reduction in the initial pH of the effluent at the end of the treatment, going from 7 to 5.5. This fact may be associated with the formation of acidic by-products that made it possible to change this parameter. It is suggested, therefore, the formation of carboxylic acids from the degradation of organic compounds. According to López et al. [27], the presence of carboxylic acids in the reaction medium, in addition to causing a reduction in pH, in the presence of iron can favor the formation of complexes. In this way, it can be stated that the presence of endogenous iron in the effluent may have enabled the association of these acids in the formation of complexes, considering that the pH, although reduced, remained above 3. This fact may also have resulted in an increase in the turbidity of the reaction medium at the end of the combined treatment, given the presence of graphite fragments detached due to the high conductivity of the evaluated matrix. Also in Table 5, it can be seen that the final BOD value was 330.56 mg·L−1 while the initial value was 711.76 mg·L−1 (Table 1), a BOD reduction of 53.56% after submitting the effluent to the combined process. About COD, a decrease of only 9.90% was obtained. This last result may be associated with the concentration of 62.19 mg·L−1 of residual H2O2 found, given that the presence of this oxidant may have positively interfered with the value obtained for COD by the hypochlorite oxidation reaction, according to Cavalcanti [28]. Therefore, it cannot be guaranteed that the COD reduction was only 9.90%, and it is necessary to carry out more detailed complementary studies to better understand the result of this parameter. In time, it is also observed in Table 5 the increase in the concentration of chlorides analyzed via precipitation of AgCl [16]. This method, which uses potassium dichromate (K2CrO4) to indicate the titration turning point, when in the presence of high concentrations of nitrogenous compounds, causes an increase in the consumption of the Cr4+ ion, interfering with the quantification by this methodology [29]. In this way, it is inferred that intermediate reactions in series with cyclic return of chlorine to the form of chloride due to the intermediate reaction to chloramine, occur during the analysis leading to an increase in the values obtained in the sample concentration for chlorides against the complex matrix. Finally, studies presented in the literature discuss the most diverse applications for energy supply via photovoltaic panels ([30], Ganyiu [31,32]). Regarding the use of off-grid systems for the treatment of organic dyes, a study developed by Ganiyu et al. [14] used a system powered by a solar energy to treat the Brilliant Blue FCF dye in an aqueous matrix. In the present work, it was possible to explore the treatment of more than one organic dye in the sanitizer industry effluent, using a combination of advanced oxidative processes powered by a photovoltaic panel in an off-grid system. This type of system guarantees full functioning of the treatment regardless of weather conditions as well as possible interruptions in supply from the electric company. In addition, it was possible to evaluate physicochemical parameters before and after submitting the effluent to the proposed treatment. In view of the above, it can be stated that the proposed treatments led to efficient degradation results, especially when analyzing the data obtained for the more complex matrix (sanitizer industry effluent). Table 6 shows the results obtained for different contaminants (dyes) and for the present study. It is possible to observe that, although the percentages of degradation achieved in this study are lower than in some studies, it was decided to work with concentrations closer to those found in the environment. Another interesting factor is the type of material used as electrode, since in this work graphite was used, which is a low-cost material, easy to be introduced into industrial WWTP. 4 Conclusion The use of a sustainable energy system is essential to guarantee and maintain the quality of water and effluent treatment in different types of industries. This study managed to promote the degradation of effluent from the sanitizing industry with high efficiency for the wavelength monitored (degradations equal to 71.47 and 85.64% for λ of 436 and 624 nm, respectively). Throughout the study it was possible to verify that combining different types of AOPs can lead to increasingly better results, which is interesting for industries as it can even be used as a natural radiation source. The search for cleaner treatment solutions arouses interest from both the scientific and industrial communities, as both have the same needs and concerns regarding water quality. This fact was observed since the proposed system also allowed reducing values of physical-chemical parameters such as BOD (53.56%). coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the treatment of dyes AY36 and AB80 using photo-Fenton (PF) and Electro-Fenton (EF) systems, powered by an off-grid photovoltaic system. Employing PF (400 mg∙L-1 H2O2) with EF, degradation reached 71.47% and 85.64% at 436 and 624 nm. The introduced off-grid photovoltaic system ensured energy supply. Notably, a reduction of 53.56% in BOD and 9.90% in COD was observed in the analyzed effluent. The integrated of PF and EF, energized by a photovoltaic panel, not only demonstrated energy efficiency but also emphasized the sustainability of the treatment, aligning with environmentally friendly and renewable energy principles in wastewater treatment.
